CatDescriptText: Mrs. Josh Horton, public relations man, Shadyside and Miss Leona Travis, postal clerk, Fifth Ward, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, April 15, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "In dispensing political patronage jobs to various groups, what should bet eh determining factor- the financial contribution of that group to the party, or the number of votes the group casts for the party?" Mrs. Josh Horton's answer reads: "I'm not in favor of the distribution of jobs on the basis of political patronage.  They should be given out on the basis of merit."  Miss Leona Travis' answer reads: "I believe there should be an equal amount of both.  The jobs should go to the persons who are best qualified and able to help, both by obtaining votes, and also through giving money."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Josh Horton wearing patterned necktie and light colored trench coat, standing in front of Brass Rail Restaurant and C.A. Michel sign, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Leona Travis wearing light colored dress with dark collar and dark gloves, holding paper bag, standing on sidewalk in front of building
